III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207- Staff Responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
2

and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency was not adequately assessing the child’s
developmental needs; and did not obtain needed services for the
child related to his development. Nor did they timely secure the
child's Early On Assessment.
Investigation Complainant
On 7/21/2023 I interviewed the complainant, Guardian Ad Litem
(GAL) X by telephone. GAL X confirmed the information in the
complaint and reported the agency is not assessing Child A’s
developmental needs. She reported Child A was born positive for
Opiates, so he may have special needs, and the agency should
have been monitoring and assessing for this, but the agency did
nothing. She said, Child A is two and a half years old now and not
talking. GAL X reported Child A has had evaluations, but the
agency was delayed in getting Child A assessed until GAL X got
involved. GAL X reported she obtained a Court order for the
agency to obtain an Early On assessment for Child A, and the
agency did not follow up on it. GAL X reported that Child A’s
mother, Parent D, who is only supposed to have supervised visits,
took him for the assessment. During that assessment Parent D
had Child A on her lap in a car and Parent D lied about what Child
A was capable of doing related to his speech. GAL X reported
knowing the information about Parent D with regards to what went
on with the Early On assessment because Early On reported it to
the foster parent, who reported the information to GAL X. GAL X
reported the foster care worker and Child A’s grandmother,
Relative C should have been at that assessment.
GAL X reported had the agency been making regular home visits
with Relative C and Child A, they would have known Child X was
not speaking and would have a better understanding of his
development.
Program Director 2
On 7/24/2023 I interviewed Program Director (PD) 2 onsite at the
agency. PD 2 denied the allegations. She reported the agency
made continued home visits with Child A and Relative C during
Child A’s placement with Relative C. She reported it is true that
Child A’s speech appears delayed. She said, Child A talks, but
perhaps should be talking more; but Child A isn’t in a “derelict”
state of delay, as GAL X had described him.
3

PD 2 reported Child A came under the agency’s care and
supervision when he was less than a month old. During home
visits with Child A and Relative C the agency was monitoring his
placement, development and progress. She said, Early On
referrals were completed for Child A during Child A’s placement
with Relative C. Wolverine made four Early On referrals. There
was ones in October 2021 and July 2022. With regards to those
two referrals, Relative C would either report Child A’s Early On
services were going well or that she could not get ahold of Early
On. Wolverine made another Early On referral in October 2022,
and there was one in July 2023.. PD 2 reported the October 2022
Early On referral was sourced out to the Chitter Chatter agency.
Wolverine did not receive the results from Chitter Chatter until
February 2023, for a reported evaluation in January 2023. The
Chitter Chatter January 2023 evaluation indicated Child A had a
minor speech delay, but he did not qualify for services. PD 2
reported at some point Wolverine questioned that Chitter Chatter
evaluation. PD 2’s supervisor, Administrator 4 contacted a Chitter
Chatter Supervisor (CCS) about the evaluation and the CCS
reported there were issues contacting Relative C. That Child A did
qualify, but Relative C never followed through. Administrator 4
inquired of the CCS why the Chitter Chatter report indicated Child
A did not qualify; and the CCS reported not knowing why..
Administrator 4 also asked the CCS why Chitter Chatter had not
contacted Wolverine, since Wolverine made the referral. The CCS
reported since Relative C and Parent D signed the consent form,
Chitter Chatter staff were contacting those individuals. CCS
reported Child A qualifies for Early On part C services, and they
would provide services. PD 2 reported another Early On
evaluation occurred on 7/25/2023 in Macomb County because
Child A was replaced to that county. An Easter Seal appointment
was set for Child A for 8/15/2023.
PD 2 was not aware of a Court ordered Early On assessment,
brought on by GAL X. She said the four Early On referrals
Wolverine completed for Child A were all initiated by Wolverine to
assess Child A’s needs, not due to a Court order. She said there
was a Court order for an Autism evaluation, which the Court
indicated Wolverine could obtained by way of a second opinion via
a health care provider other than Child A’s primary health care
provider. She reported a change in the health provider seemed to
have been what GAL X wanted. PD 2 admitted she tried to
explain to GAL X how continuity with a health care provider is
important and that Wolverine tries to maintain this, and not have
caregivers changing doctors. PD2 said Wolverine did not object
4

to the second opinion, to the Autism assessment; and did in fact
follow through on it. Child A had a Sprout Evaluation on
6/27/2023, which was to assess for Autism and other
developmental disorders. During that evaluation Child A was not
diagnosed with Autism but was diagnosed with an adjustment
disorder and mixed receptive language disorder. The Sprout
assessment/evaluator recommended a structured play group, a
comprehensive speech and language evaluation; and that Child A
may also benefit from receiving an occupational therapy
evaluation. Continued consultation with a pediatric neurologist
was also strongly recommended; and a list of possible Support
Coordinators to assist with getting/completing the needed
referrals/ service linkage and accesses to the recommended
evaluations were also indicated by Sprout. The agency is
following up with those recommendations.
PD 2 provided me a copy of the Sprout Evaluation, which showed
the psychological evaluation and indicated diagnostic and
recommendation information reported by PD 2.
Foster Care Worker 3
On 8/2/2023 I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3 onsite at
the agency. FCW 3 did not recall GAL X recommending that an
Early On referral be completed for Child A. FCW 3 reported for
children in foster care they routinely complete an Early On referral
for the child. She completed three Early On referrals for Child A.
She was assigned to Child A’s case sometime in September of
2021 and on 10/19/2021 she completed and Early On referral as
the new worker on the case. That referral was also completed
because the agency wanted to know if Child A was developing on
target as he appeared to be. The Early On assessment from that
October 2021 referral did not occur due to communication issues
between Relative C and the Early On agency. Relative C reported
she was calling Early On, and she was not receiving a call back.
Early On indicated Relative C was not following. After two to
three incidents like that, Early On dropped the referral.
Thereafter, with various reports by Child A’s pediatrician indicating
he was developing, Wolverine saw Child A as developing age
appropriately.
FCW 3 completed another Early On referral for Child A on
10/14/2022, after a meeting with Relative C and Parent D, where
both were reporting concern with Child A’s speech. Child A was
twenty-two months old, and Child A was babbling more so, than
using words. FCW 3 also noticed that, thus the referral. FCW 3
reported the October 2022 Early On referral generated the Chitter
5

Chatter assessment. FCW 3’s reporting of the circumstances of
that Chitter Chatter assessment were as described by PD 2 with
Child A reportedly not qualifying, though he had; and the agency
following up on that matter.
FCW 3’s third Early On referral was on 7/5/2023, because Child A
moved to Macomb County. The evaluation for this July 2023
referral was on 7/25/2023, with Child A qualifying for speech and
occupational therapy for a speech delay and impulse control.
FCW 3 reported a meeting with Early On is scheduled for
8/4/2023 to discuss goals for Child A.
Document Review:
Child A’s MiSACWIS case record, and file documents which
showed:
• He is a temporary court ward, who was born positive to
THC and Hydromorphone.
• He was placed under Wolverine’s care and supervision on
1/14/2021.
• He was placed in Relative C’s care on 1/13/2021 until
6/6/2023.
• Three Early On referrals completed for Child A dated
1/21/2021(from Oakland County DHHS) 10/19/2021,
1/21/2022, 10/13/2022, and 7/5/2023(from Wolverine).
• Ages, & Stages Questionnaires completed by Child A’s
caregiver examining Child A’s development dated,
3/5/2021(for two months of age);5/18/2021(for six months
of age);1/19/2022(for 12 months of age) 3/9/2022 for (18
months of age; 8/24/2022(for 24 months of age) and
7/27/2023 for 30 months of age) showing Child A,
development was being tracked.
• Medical exams/well child examinations for Child A for four
weeks, two months, six months, nine months, 12 months
15, months and 18 months showing no concerns or
complaint, or indicating well child. A 1/12/2023 well child
exam for Child A’s two year old examination documented
a delay with Child A’s speech and that the child would be
referred to Early On.
• A Chitter Chatter Integrative report dated 1/17/2022(should
have read 1/17/2023. The report indicated:
✓ There was an initial Early On referral related to this
assessment on 10/14/2022 due to concerns
expressed by Child A’s assigned case worker,
relative foster parent and birth mother.
✓ Child A was 24 months old at the time of this
assessment.
6

✓ The Evaluation took place via Zoom with Child A
and Parent D. Relative C, his primary caregiver was
also present during the evaluation, with Parent D
answering the evaluation questions.
✓ Child A was assessed to have no physical, social, or
emotional delays.
✓ Child A’s adaptive behavior was assessed to not be
within normal limit; and he had a receptive language
delay.
✓ Child A will qualify for Early-on Part C services.
Chitter Chatter will provide the family with
information, literature, recommendations and
activities to use regarding Child A’s development.
• A 7/25/2023 Macomb ISD Multidisciplinary Evaluation
Team Eligibility Recommendation report which indicated:
✓ Child A was referred by Wayne County Early On and
the family’s pediatrician related to concerns
regarding Child A’s speech and language
development.
✓ The Team recommended that Child A be determined
eligible for special education programs/services
under the category(ies) of Speech & Language
Impairment.
• A Sprout Evaluation Center, Psychological Evaluation
dated 6/27/2023, which ruled out Autism and indicated a
mixed receptive language delay; and findings and
recommendations as indicated by PD 2 during my interview
with her.
• Consistent foster home/caregiver home visits by agency
staff for placement and parenting time visits.
Analysis Child A is currently a two- and half-year male. The agency was
monitoring the child’s development, completed at least three Early
On referrals for the child with that regard; and sought to obtain the
services which were ultimately recommended in the two
evaluations that resulted from those Early On referrals.
The evidence does not support the allegations that the agency
was not assessing Child A needs, failed to obtain services for
those needs, or that they failed to obtain an Early On
referral/assessment for Child A. Nor does it support a lack of
workers not working directly with the child, their families, and other
relevant individuals related to the service plan.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
7

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207- Staff Responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency is not adequately assessing for safety related to the
child’s health and behaviors, his birth parents, and his
permanency plan.
Investigati Complainant
on On 7/21/2023 I interviewed the complainant, Guardian Ad Litem
(GAL) X by telephone. GAL X confirmed the information in the
complaint and reported the agency was not adequately assessing
for Child A’s safety for the following reasons: Parent D is
supposed to have supervised visits with Child A, but Relative C
may have been allowing Parent D to have the child for
unsupervised visits. Parent D was the one who took Child A to an
Early On evaluation, when Relative C and the foster care worker
should have been there. Parent D and the Child A’s father, Parent
E were reportedly in a Facebook post where the two of them were
in bed with together with Child A. GAL X did not report whether
she saw this Facebook post or was told about it. There is
concern Parent D’s supervised visits are not really supervised.
The Facebook photo may be an indication of that.
GAL X reported when Child A was replaced from Relative C’s
home he came to the new foster home with marijuana in his
clothing. Additionally, the clothing he brought were stained and
many were too small. He was also extremely dirty to the point
when the foster parent bathed him, the water was filthy. GAL X
reported if the agency was making required monthly home visits to
Relative C’s home they would have been aware that Relative C
was not providing for Child A’s need. The agency would have
known Relative C was allowing Child A to just watch television,
was not providing stimulation or adequate nutrition for him,
because Relative C has allowed Child A to be an overweight child.
GAL X also expressed concern the agency was or had been
exploring Relative C an adoption plan for Child A, especially
given all that was going on with Relative C.
8

GAL X also reported Child A has head banging behavior, which
has resulted in him having a boney ridge bruise on his forehead.
GAL X said the agency told Child A’s new foster parent, that Child
A had no behavior issues; the agency alleged Child A’s head
banging was a new behavior. GAL X said she did not see the
bruise on Child A’s head, but it was reported by Foster Parent B
and Foster Parent G. GAL X found it hard to believe the head
banging behavior was new. She reported Foster Parent G, who is
a doctor, termed Child A’s bruise as a “boney bruise” and reported
one would not get that type of bruise from recent behavior.
GAL X further reported the agency is not adequately assessing
Parent E. She reported Parent E said he did not have a home,
but the agency is seeking to place Child A with Parent E who is
living with his girlfriend and or mother. Additionally, Parent E has
extensive drugs related issues, and he is a convicted felon. GAL
X said Parent E also has no relationship Child A; and Parent E
only became Child A’s legal father in April of 2023. She said the
agency was seeking permanent custody, but not this plan with
Parent E, which the court is adopting. GAL X expressed concern
that Parent E could easily relapse. And given Parent E’s issues,
GAL X question Parent E’s appropriateness as the permanency
plan for Child A. GAL X is seeking or may seek to appeal the
Court’s order to place Child E with Parent E.
Program Director 2 & Foster Care Worker 3
On 7/24/2023 I interviewed Program Director (PD) 2 onsite at the
agency regarding the allegations. I interviewed Foster Care
Worker (FCW) 3 onsite at the agency on 8/2/2023. I also spoke
with FCW 3 about aspects of the allegations by telephone on
8/8/2023.
Parent D’s supervised or unsupervised contact with Child A:
• PD2 reported it is true that Parent D parenting time is
supervised, but the Court has allowed there to be a
designee to supervisor those parenting visits; and Relative
C is the person the Court allowed as the designee. PD 2
said GAL X is aware to this; so PD 2 is not sure why GAL X
may have an issue with that now. With respect to the
parenting times, PD 2 reported when Parent D’s visitations
were at the office, they could tell Parent D had spent a lot
of time with Child A, but parenting times had and have
gone well. PD 2 reported from what the agency knows,
Relative C has been in the line of sight for Parent D’s
supervised parenting time with Child A. PD 2 reported
when a concern is brought to their attention about a
9

possible lack of supervision by Relative C related to the
parent/child parenting visitations, they can address it. Like
on 6/5/2023 when Parent D was outside with Child A
playing and the two were not in Relative C’s line of sight.
PD 2 reported she reminded Relative C about Relative C’s
oversight responsibility. PD 2 said when they have known
about parenting supervision concerns or issues they have
acted on them. They have advised GAL X of that; and that
they can only do something about issues the agency knows
about.
PD 2 reported it was true that at one point, the plan had
been for Relative C to adopt Child A, because the agency
had submitted a supplemental petition to terminate on
Parent D; and Parent E’s location was unknown. A plan of
adoption by Relative C would have been the normal plan of
action in that scenario, but GAL X was disgusted with that
plan. PD 2 reported all of that was before Parent E came
on the scene; and before all the other information got
disclosed related to Relative C that resulted in Child A’s
need to be replaced. A latter act and move that Wolverine
kept GAL X informed of step by step, and which the Foster
Care Review Board (FCRB)agreed with.
As for Parent D and Parent E living together or having a
Facebook post of the two parents in bed with Child A, PD 2
reported the following: It appears from what FCW 3
reported that the foster parent looked Parent D up on
Facebook and saw the picture and reported it. The picture
did not appear to be a selfie, someone took the photo,
which may have been from October of 2022. PD 2 did not
report how she knew that possible date or the significant of
such. She said Relative C is the designee for Child A’s
parent/child parenting visitation, and Wolverine relied on
Relative C giving them adequate information. She said
Parent D and Parent E are not living together. Parent E
resides with his parents. Parent D is living at Parent E old
house, and Parent E reports wanting Parent D out of that
home.
PD 2 acknowledged that Parent D may have been at an
Early On assessment with Child A; and may have reported
information to the evaluators, but that would have been in
addition to Relative C being there. PD 2 reported, Parent
D’s visitations with Child A is the one consistent thing
Parent D has done. PD 2 reported Parent D has not acted
10

on any other required mandates; and the agency still
believes it is in Child A’s best interest for Parent D’s rights
to be terminated to achieved permanency for Child A, Thus,
Wolverine still plans to move forward with termination of
Parent D’s rights.
• FCW 3 reported supervision of Child A’s and Parent D’s
parenting visits was approved by the Court and the agency
sometime in May or June of 2021, before FCW 3 was the
assigned worker on the case. FCW 3 provided me a copy
of the 5/5/2021 court order showing that a designee could
supervise the parenting visits. FCW 3 said Relative C
would report to her that all parent/child parenting visitations
were being supervised; and would provide her with the
times and dates of those parenting visits.
FCW 3 said she did not have any reason to believe
Relative C was allowing Parent D to just take Child A
unsupervised. FCW 3 said, at times, she would visit
Relative C’s home during the same times that Parent D
was having her parenting time, and she did not observe
concerns. FCW 3 affirmed PD 2 reporting that other than
regular visits with Child A, Parent D has not been compliant
with other requirements required for reunification. FCW 3
further affirmed information reported by PD 2 related to the
reported Facebook post. FCW 3 did not see the post. Nor
had she referenced it with Relative C because when the
foster parent went back to see the post/picture, it was gone.
FCW 3 reported she has had a number of conservations
with Relative C and Parent D that all the parenting visits
have to be supervised; and both parents denied them being
otherwise.
FCW 3 reported Parent D, as well as Parent E denied a
relationship with one another; and she has no specific
information that they are in a relationship.
Marijuana in Child A’s clothing, him being extremely dirty
when he was replaced from Relative C’s home and his
general care while with Relative C:
• PD 2 reported on 6/6/2023 she grabbed Child A’s diaper
bag as she was moving him from Relative C care. After
arriving at the foster home and reaching into the diaper bag
to remove clothing for Child A, she saw a small container at
the bottom of the diaper bag. The container contained
residue of marijuana leaves and or seeds. It was not a
11

joint. PD 2 called Parent D about this container; and Parent
D apologized, said it was hers. Parent D said it should not
have been there. PD 2 did not report whether Parent D
reported how or why the container was placed in the diaper
bag. PD 2 did not report there being a concern of this type
in the past.
PD 2 reported the agency completed regular ongoing
monthly visits to Relative C’s home. There were general
concerns with Relative C not always following up with the
agency on phone calls, her rescheduling home visits,
medical or dental timeliness, and her home at time showing
signs of clutter. There were not concerns around Relative
C not feeding Child A, his clothes being too small or reports
of him being dirty or unkept. PD 2 reported when she
replaced Child A from Relative C’s care on 6/6/2023 Child
A had dirt on him, which Relative C reported was from him
playing outside. Child A was not filthy from head to toe, as
alleged. Nor did Foster Parent B report such as was
indicated in the complaint. Foster Parent B informed PD 2
via text that Child A loved bath time and rested well. Foster
Parent B never reported that Child A was so dirty that his
bath water was filthy.
PD 2 provided a copy the text messages between she and
Foster Parent B following Child A’s placement on 6/6/2023.
The texts affirmed PD 2’s reporting about bath time/ the
foster parent not reporting dirty bath water.
• FCW 3 reported information pertaining to the marijuana
issue, Child A allegedly being dirty and having stained or a
lack of clothing upon his placement to Foster Parent B’s
and Foster Parent G’s home was something that came to
PD 2’s attention, not hers’. She said she learned that
information may have been reported by Foster Parent B to
GAL X. FCW 3 said Foster Parent B did not make a
complaint or concern directly to her.
FCW 3 reported during her monthly visits to see Child A in
his placement with Relative C, his clothing and how he was
doing in the home was always assessed via her
observation. She would also complete a Safety
Assessment (this is documented via a checklist form
indicating the home’s condition/safety) for each visit. She
said Relative C’s home would often have some clutter,
Relative C would report Child A was sleeping well, doing
12

well, and FCW 3 observed him to be safe and well. FCW 3
was not aware of Child A not having sufficient or adequate
food or activities. She had observed him playing with toys.
Child A’s head banging behavior and resulting boney bruise:
• PD 2 denied the agency being awareness of Child A having
heading banging behavior prior to 6/5/2023. On the
aforementioned date, while visiting Relative C’s new
residence, PD 2 observed Child A to bang his head on the
window. Child A had run forward, hit his head, and then
threw himself back and had a tantrum. PD 2 said she
questioned Relative C and Parent D, who was also present,
whether Child A had always displayed this behavior, and
they reported Child A only did so when he was mad.
Relative C and Parent D did not report how often Child A
got mad. The two parents reported talking with Child A’s
doctor about the behavior. They reported the doctor did not
give the behavior much attention, advised them to not
reinforce the behavior.
PD 2 did not observe any mark or bruise to Child A’s
forehead at the time of her 6/5/2023 home visit with
Relative C. PD 2 said Child A’s hair was covering that part
of his head. The next day, on 6/6/2023 during Child A’s
replacement and completion of a body chart, PD 2 noticed
a red mark at the top of Child A’s head/hairline. The mark
protruded out. At that time, PD 2 informed Foster Parent B
and Foster Parent B’s husband, Foster Parent G that PD 2
did not know about Child A’s head banging prior to the
6//5/2023. PD 2 said it was at this point that Foster Parent
G, a doctor, described the type of bruise on Child A’s
forehead; and said one gets that from repeated head
banging. That day Child A was also observed being at
ease, playing roughly, tumbling, but not head banging.
PD 2 reported the agency contacted Child A’s health
provider related to his head banging and the information
reported by Relative C and Parent D,. The health care
provider disputed Relative C’s and Parent D’s claim and
said they did not know about Child A’s head banging. The
health care provider had no problem giving Child A a
referral for a helmet. In the interim Foster Parent G
obtained a temporary helmet for Child A. Child A has the
regular helmet now.
13

• FCW 3 reported she had observed Child A to tantrum by
throwing himself down, if told no; but she denied observing
or being aware of Child A having head banging behaviors.
She did not become aware of that behaviors until after it
came to PD 2’s attention on 6/5/2023. FCW 3 became
aware of the ‘boney” bruise on Child A’s forehead, what
Foster Parent G termed it, and how it likely came to be via
PD 2 also. FCW 3 said Relative C and Parent D never
reported Child A to have head banging behaviors. She
said during the home visits to Relative C’s, she always
asked Relative C and Parent D (who would, at times, be at
Relative C’s home for parenting time) whether Child A had
behavior concerns or new behaviors, and both Relative C
and Parent D would indicate Child A had none.
FCW 3 acknowledged Child A’s head banging behavior
continued after 6/5/2023. FCW 3 completed two foster
home visits with Child A’ in Foster Parent B’s and Foster
Parent G’s home, and FCW observed the head banging
behavior. She advised the foster parents to follow up with
the primary health care provider, which they did. The
primary health care provider recommended a protective
helmet and gave the foster family a prescription for the
helmet. In the interim, as reported by PD 2 the foster
parents obtained a soft helmet for Child A. FCW 3 reported
the foster parents were also advised to have Child A wear
the helmet all day, to watch him closely, and provide bear
like hug to calm him with if needed to prevent banging
behavior.
The agency is not adequately assessing Parent E:
• PD 2 denied the allegation. She explained that Parent E

signed an affidavit of parentage on 4/6/2023. PD 2

14

PD 2 reported Wolverine has assessed Parent E for

Parent E has past drug related issues and has a lengthy

She said he also has a job, housing and is complying with

PD 2 reported the DHHS monitor, who has been at the last

• FCW 3 denied the agency not assessing Parent E. She
reported that in August 2022 Parent E really began to
engage with the agency. She advised that in the past
Parent E had been recorded as the putative father, and in
October 2022, Parent E initiated the DNA process. She
said, at first Parent E was apprehensive about planning for

Parent D’s chances. Once Parent E saw that Parent D was
not doing what was required to bring about Child A’s return
home, Parent E completed the DNA process in January

2023. FCW 3 said, Parent E has housing and has provided

related to Parent E’s parole, compliance with that parole,
and residence with his parents. FCW 3 said Parent E had
put off her checking out his parents’ home due to some

parents have adopted one of Parent E’s sons; so, if placed

FCW 3 reported though there is an objection by GAL X
about Child A’s placement with Parent E, the Court has

Document Review:
• Child A’s MISACWIS case record and social work contacts
which showed no missed monthly home visits with the child
and his care providers.
• Copies of a year’s worth of Safety Assessments, which:

✓ For 6/8/2023, 6/22/2023, 7/7/2023 and 7/19/2023 in

Safety Assessment, all others indicated, “Yes” to the
question, does the child have adequate clothing
(based on the child’s current
size/weather/appropriate/ minimum of a week’s
worth). The 6/8/2023 Safety Assessment also
indicated yes, with a written note that the “FCW
brought more clothes, shoes and toys”.
• Copies of a years’ worth of monthly foster home visit sheets
forms from 7//26/2022 to 7/30/2023. The foster home visit

The home visit sheets showed the FCW engaged the

doing/progressing, Early On referrals/assessments, speech

16

needs, referrals for services, visitation requirements for

Analysis The agency was completing required homes visits to the child’s

Additionally, the agency completed a home assessment and

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421- Visitation and family time; in person
Section contact.
Description (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child and
the foster parent, if applicable in the child’s placement at least
once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not do adequate monitoring of the child by making
required monthly home visits to the grandmother's home. The
grandmother was homeless as of October 2022, but the agency
did not know this; and did not report this to the GAL until June
2023.
Investigation Complainant
On 7/21/2023 I interviewed the complainant, Guardian Ad Litem
(GAL) X by telephone. GAL X reported the agency must have not
been making required monthly home visit to Child A’s placement
with Relative C. She reported if the agency had been making
17

adequate home visits they would have known Relative C had a
problem with housing. Additionally, they would have been able to
see that Child A was not receiving the structure that he needed
related to his needs. GAL X reported there were times she had to
contact the agency related to getting in contact with Relative C,
because Relative C’s phone was out. Additionally, that there
were times Relative C would not allow GAL X to have GAL X’s
visits at Relative C’s home. Relative C would say Relative C
would bring Child A to GAL X’s office and the visit would take
place there. GAL X said she had multiple facetime visit with
Relative C and Child A. GAL X reported some of those visit were
during COVID.
GAL X reported after the agency reported Relative C’s
homelessness in June 2023, Relative C was then living with a
relative that had a Pitbulls and a cluttered home. The agency did
not seem very concerned about that, and PD 2 wanted to reserve
Child A’s placement with Relative C. GAL X expressed safety
concerns and questioned why PD 2 would seek to maintain Child
A's placement in that environment. GAL X acknowledged Child A
was replaced from Relative C/ was not maintained in the relative
home Relative C had moved to.
Program Director 2
On 7/24/2023 I interviewed Program Director (PD) 2 onsite at the
agency. PD 2 reported Relative C lived in Belleville, Michigan
and the FCW 3 always saw Child A with Relative C in the same
home/location. PD 2 reported an unusual incident came up at
FCW 3’s 5/11/2023 home visit to Relative C’s home. The worker
saw an extra bed in the home in an inappropriate area. Relative C
would not tell FCW 3 a clear explanation as to why the bed was
there. FCW 3 advised Relative C to remove the bed, and
explained the safety issue, because mattress was in a
nonapproved area of the home. The incident ultimately triggered
Wolverine’s licensing department’s intervention.
The agency’s licensing department staff reached out to Relative
C’s landlord on 6/5/2023. At that time the landlord reported
Relative C had not lived at the Belleville apartment home since
October 2022. A specific date in October 2022 was not reported,
and PD 2 did not know whether the landlord reported whether
Relative C had moved or had been evicted. Nor whether their
agency’s licensing staff had asked for that distinction. PD 2 said
Relative C’s home was a duplex apartment and Relative C had a
relationship with the family next door. PD 2 said there was
nothing that would have led them to know or believe Relative C
18

did not live there. Relative C was home for the FCW 3’s home
visits and Relative C’s and Child A’s belonging appeared in place.
PD 2 reported after their licensing staff’s contact with Relative C’s
landlord on 6/5/2023, she made contact with Relative C by
telephone, and then in person. Relative C reported she and Child
A were residing with a friend, Person H in Inkster Michigan. PD 2
said she and a coworker spent two hours at this Inkster home.
She talked with Relative C, Person H and assessed the home for
safety. Prior to the home visit she contacted children services
related to the situation with the placement and Relative C.
Relative C told PD 2 she moved; and since she did to think she
was allowed to move; she did not tell the agency because she did
not want to jeopardy Child A’s placement with her. Relative C
said she thought the agency would remove Child A from her care.
PD 2 reported she advised Relative C that her reasoning was not
accurate, did make sense; and PD 2 asked Relative C what was
really going on, but Relative C kept reporting the same statement,
as before.
PD 2 affirmed that their assessment of Person H’s home
confirmed some if not all that may have been reported in the
complaint related to the home being clutter, and there being pit
bulls. She said some rooms in the home had clutter stacked from
floor to ceiling, medication was on a table, cleaning supplies were
not stored properly out of reach, and no fire/ carbon monoxide
detector. Child A and Relative C were in a separate room from
Person H but were sharing a bed. PD 2 advised that she did not
believes that Relative C was living in this home, because PD 2 did
not see many of Child A’s or Relative C’s person things. But
Relative C and Person H insisted Relative C was staying there.
Neither reported when Relative C had moved into the home. PD 2
reported Wolverine safety planned with Relative C and Person H
for that evening. Wolverine purchased a pack and play for Child A
to sleep in, a carbon monoxide/fire detector for the kitchen and
obtained a baby gate which was used to block off Child A from the
hallway and kitchen, keeping him from the cleaning supplies.
Person H said the dog were friendly and Child A has been around
then, but Person H agreed to keep the dog outside, and to lock up
her medication immediately. Relative C signed the safety plan
and PD 2 was to return the next date, which she did.
PD 2 reported she contacted GAL X and informed her of Relative
C’s living situation/move on 6/5/2023. PD 2 admitted that she told
GAL X that in most cases when children are with relatives the
agency tries to preserve the placement, when that goal is feasible.
19

PD 2 reported after some discussion and from seeing Person H’s
home, the agency removed Child A from Relative C’s care the
next date on 6/6/2023. PD 2 reported the move was based on
safety concerns at that time and what was in Child A best interest,
not any alleged threat from the GAL. She said Relative C was
provided a DHS-30- Foster Parent/Caregiver Notification of Move
regarding the replacement. Relative C appealed to the FCRB and
the FCRB agreed with Wolverine’s replacement decision.
Foster Care Worker 3
On 8/2/2023 I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3 onsite at
the agency. FCW 3 affirmed information as reported by PD 2
related to monthly home visit being conducted regularly to
Relative C’s home. Additionally, the results of a relative home
visit on 5/11/2023 whereby FCW 3 observed a mattress on the
floor of Relative C’s home in area with no egress and what
occurred thereafter with the agency licensing intervention, and
there on. FCW 3 said Relative C denied anyone else living in the
home, and Relative 3 moved the mattress, as that was a red flag
she reported it to her supervisor and children services complaint
was called in. She reported there had been another time whereby
she had observed adults and children in the home, and she
reported that also. Relative C’s explanation about that seemed
plausible and ICHAT occurred for the adults then.
FCW 3 denied having any suspicious or inclinations that Relative
C had not been living in the Belleville home since October 2022.
She said Relative C would either be in the home when she arrived
for the home visitor or Resident C was arriving home just after
FCW 3 arrived. FCW 3 reported not thinking more about the fact
that Relative C was arriving to home after her arrival, because
although Relative C did not work, Relative C reported she was
attending to medical needs and or errands. Those explanations
seemed valid at the time. Additionally, Relative C’s and Child A
belongings, including the couch, Child A’s crib, toys were still in
the home during each of the visits. In hindsight FCW 3 surmises
Relative C’s landlord who is either a relative or friend to Relative C
may have aided Relative C in hiding her housing situation from the
agency.
Document Review:
• Safety Assessment checklists and home visits sheets as
described earlier.
• Monthly home visit social work contacts showing home
visits were made to Relative C’s home; and for issues
observed on a previous homes visits, action was taken.
20

• A copy of the 6/5/2023 Safety Plan Wolverine completed
with Relative C on 6/5/2022 which outlined the
information/safety measures PD 2 reported Wolverine put
in place for that evening.
Analysis The evidence does not support the allegations. Nor a lack of
monthly home visits by the agency to assess Child A’s placement.
Home visits were occurring. Relative C was somehow able to
conceal her housing situation/homelessness from the agency with
the aid from others.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12411- Clothing.
Section An agency must ensure that a foster child has the minimum
Description required clothing specified by the department’s policy and leaves
the foster home with not less than the minimum required clothing.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency’s director told the foster parent to give the child's
clothing back to his grandmother which violates the rule of a
child's clothing being the child's.
Investigation Complainant
On 7/21/2023 I interviewed the complainant, Guardian Ad Litem
(GAL) X by telephone. GAL X reported it was reported that Child
A’s clothing were stained and were not appropriated. Additionally,
PD 2 told Foster Parent B to give Child A’s smaller clothing back
to Relative C which is against State policy and rule.
Program Director 2
On 7/24/2023 I interviewed Program Director (PD) 2 onsite at the
agency. I also had followed up email contact with PD 2 about
Child A’s sufficiency of clothing on 8/12/2023 and 8/21/2023.
PD 2 said she never told Foster Parent B Child A’s too small
clothing had to go back to Relative C. She told Foster Parent B if
there were clothing items that were not useable or did not fit Child
A, PD 2 could give them back to Relative C. She said she never
got any clothes back and the agency purchased clothing for child
A the next day. She advised that since Child A’s move from
Relative C was unplanned a clothing checklist was not completed.
She reported that typically a clothing checklist does not occur at
replacements, but they do them to determine initial clothing order
requests when the children come into care, and for special
clothing order requests. She reported she told Foster Parent B
21

that day that if Child A needed something the agency would
purchase it for him.
PD 2 said she and Foster Parent B went through Child A’s items
the day he moved into the foster home; and immediately after
Foster Parent B put the clothing in the washer. They discussed
items Child A needed and Wolverine purchased summer items for
Child A the next day, so as to get him started with any clothing he
needed.
Foster Care Worker 3
On 8/2/2023 I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3 onsite at
the agency. FCW 3 indicated Child A had clothing and the agency
purchased clothing and toys for him when he was replaced from
Relative C’s home. She reported she assesses for a child’s
clothing needs during monthly home visits. She does that by
talking with the caregiver about what the child has or needs; and
examining the child’s clothing closet/area; as she did with Child A.
She then documents on the monthly Safety Assessment whether
the child has adequate clothing.
FCW 3 was not aware of PD 2 telling Foster Parent B that Foster
Parent B could or should give Child A’s small clothes back to
Relative C.
Foster Parent B
On 8/8/2023, I interviewed Foster Parent B by telephone. Foster
Parent B was not sure of the agency’s clothing policy but admitted
she may have signed a document about it when she was first
licensed.
Foster Parent B reported when Child A was placed in her foster
home he, did not have pants on and he was dirty. She said, Child
A had some clothing in a diaper bag, and PD 2 did not leave the
bag because of what PD 2 reported finding in the bag. The
clothing PD 2 left had stains, and some things were too small.
The clothing were sizes 18-24 months and Child A is a size four.
Foster Parent B said Wolverine purchased some clothes for Child
A, like Croc shoes (which were too small) tank tops, and shorts.
Foster Parent B reported she and her husband also purchased
clothes for Child A. She reported being surprised that they would
not get reimbursed for the clothing, but PD 2 told them they could
not get reimbursed for the clothing because Child A was not
eligible for a new clothing order. She said PD 2 told them to not
throw anything out, that too small items would go back to Relative
C. Foster Parent B was not sure if that was because the items
were purchased by Relative C.
22

Document Review:
• The agency’s clothing policy which indicated:
✓ To foster parents the daily clothing stipend amount,
semiannual clothing supplements information; and
the combined monthly stipend of the regular foster
care stipend to provide for the child’s needed
clothing.
✓ Other expectations for the foster parent/caregiver
and that the form is to be signed by the foster
parent/caregiver and agency.
• Copy of a Clothing Policy signed by Foster Parent B and
Foster Parent G on 2/25/2020.
• Copies of a year’s worth of Safety Assessments for Child A,
which: indicated, “Yes” to the question, does the child have
adequate clothing (based on the child’s current
size/weather/appropriate/ minimum of a week’s worth).
• A Safety Assessment for Child A dated 6/8/2023, indicating
Child A had adequate clothing, and that the FCW brought
more clothes and shoes for Child A
Analysis PD 2 and the foster parent reported somewhat conflicting
reporting as to what PD 2 told the foster parent related to what to
do with Child A’s too small clothing.
There is insufficient evidence to support the allegation or that
Child A did not have the minimum required clothing.
Consultation & Technical Assistance:
The agency was advised that the completion of the DHS-3377
Clothing Inventory Checklist at a child’s replacement may aid it in
making and showing a clearer determination of the child’s clothing
needs and rule compliance documentation.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLSHED.
II. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
